channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Netanyahu to Iran: ‘Do Not Test Israel’s Resolve’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who spoke at the Munich Security Conference in Germany, on Sunday, brandished a remnant of what he said was an Iranian drone shot down in Israeli airspace.
item.media:credit: Lennart Preiss/MSC Munich Security Conference, via Reuters
item.description: Brandishing what he said was part of an Iranian drone shot down by the Israeli military, the prime minister warned in a speech in Munich against crossing Israel’s “red lines.”
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Russian Trolls Were Sloppy, but Indictment Still ‘Points at the Kremlin’
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, center right, with President Vladimir Putin at his school lunches factory outside St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2010.
item.description: When Russian trolling techniques were exported to the United States, it seems to have been done with a lack of discipline and secrecy. But that does not mean the operation lacked high-level support.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: The Troll Farm: What We Know About 13 Russians Indicted by the U.S.
item.media:description: 55 Savushkina Street in St. Petersburg, Russia, the former home of the Internet Research Agency.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Employees and associates of the Internet Research Agency, a shadowy company based in St. Petersburg, are accused of trying to interfere in the 2016 election.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Brendan Cox, Husband of Murdered U.K. Lawmaker, Resigns Over Abuse Accusations
item.media:description: Brendan Cox, husband of the slain British Parliament member Jo Cox, in London in 2016. He has apologized for past behavior but denied other accusations of abuse.
item.description: The husband of Jo Cox stepped down from two charities created in her memory over allegations of inappropriate conduct from 2015.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Iran Plane Crashes Into Mountain, Killing All 66 Aboard
item.media:description: Distraught relatives of passengers of the crashed Aseman Airline flight gathered at the Mehr-Abad Airport in Tehran, Iran, on Sunday.
item.description: Aseman Airlines said the plane was carrying 60 passengers and six crew members when it went down south of Tehran.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Meet America’s Syrian Allies Who Helped Defeat ISIS
item.media:description: Najim Muhammad, 38, deputy commander of the Manbij Military Council, at its headquarters in Manbij, Syria.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: They are Arabs and Kurds, men and women, young and old. Meet some of the fighters who teamed up with the United States to drive the Islamic State out of northeastern Syria.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: As Ramaphosa Hails a ‘New Dawn,’ South Africans See More of the Same
item.media:description: South Africa’s new president, Cyril Ramaphosa, arriving at Parliament in Cape Town on Friday for his first state of the nation address.
item.description: Few in Soweto township expect change now that Cyril Ramaphosa is president. But none can imagine voting against the African National Congress.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: 4 Israelis Hurt by Bomb Set in Flag at Gaza Fence, Igniting Night of Fighting
item.media:description: Palestinian demonstrators taking cover during clashes with the Israeli military in the Gaza Strip on Friday.
item.description: Israel responded with two waves of airstrikes on an attack tunnel and military targets across Gaza. A rocket fired at Israel struck the roof of a home but did not explode.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: In Japan, a Liberal Maverick Is Seeking to Lead a Conservative Party
item.media:description: Amid Japan’s usually stodgy political world, Taro Kono, the foreign minister, tweets pictures of macarons, pokes fun at himself on social media and doesn’t always toe the party line.
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.description: Taro Kono, a U.S.-educated political blue blood who has made a name as a liberal nonconformist, is positioning himself to one day replace Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: In Colombia Border Town, Desperate Venezuelans Sell Hair to Survive
item.media:description: Wilya Hernández, a Venezuelan who crossed the border into Cúcuta, Colombia, breast feeds her daughter, 2. They sleep on the city’s streets.
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.description: Fleeing crime and economic crisis, more than half a million Venezuelans have entered Colombia, with many homeless, begging for food and suffering abuse.
item.dc:creator: JOE PARKIN DANIELS

item.title: Brazil Looks to Crack Down on Fake News Ahead of Bitter Election
item.media:description: Demonstrators shouted slogans in support of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in São Paulo last month. The former Brazilian president is running again this year.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: Officials from the judiciary and law enforcement are teaming up to try to prevent voters from being misled, arguing that freedom of speech cannot come at the cost of a tainted election.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Theresa May, in Munich, Calls for Swift Security Pact and Offers Concession
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday in Germany.
item.description: The British prime minister, who said the pact should be signed before a “Brexit” deal, announced that Britain would respect the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Pope Revives Sexual Abuse Commission Amid Criticism of Vatican
item.media:description: Pope Francis leaving the Basilica of Saint Anselm before Ash Wednesday Mass in Rome. His initial defense of a priest accused of abuse had outraged Chile.
item.description: An American cardinal will head the commission, the Vatican said, and it will include survivors of clergy abuse.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: For Taiwanese, Tests of Loyalty to China Bring Trouble in Workplace
item.media:description: Man-Tzu Tuan, 19, was fired from her job at a restaurant in Sydney after her boss asked her whether Taiwan was part of China.
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Chinese employers in Australia, mirroring Beijing’s strong-arm tactics, have fired workers who do not recognize Taiwan as part of China.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and XIUZHONG XU

item.title: Catalan Politician Leaves for Switzerland Days Before Court Date
item.media:description: The Catalan lawmaker Anna Gabriel in Barcelona, Spain, in 2016. Her political party said on Saturday that she had traveled to Geneva to prepare her legal defense.
item.description: It is not clear whether Anna Gabriel, a leading separatist, will appear in Madrid this week to face possible charges of sedition and rebellion.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: How the E.U.’s Migrant Crisis Reached the Streets of Brussels
item.media:description: Migrants in Maximilian Park in Brussels last year. The Belgian government has ordered police raids on informal camps and homeless shelters.
item.description: Sudanese migrants are increasingly visible in Brussels, around train stations, in public squares and parks, sometimes sleeping in the streets.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Revives Concerns About European Defense Plans, Rattling NATO Allies
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, during a meeting on the second day of the defense ministers council meeting at NATO headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.
item.description: After pressing European nations to spend more on their security, Americans now worry that their projects could weaken the Atlantic alliance and block U.S. defense contractors from deals.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Permanent Structured Cooperation on Security and Defense

item.title: Deadly Attack at Church in Russian Region of Dagestan
item.description: A gunman killed at least five people and wounded several others, Tass reported. Some news outlets said there was more than one attacker.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and OLEG MATSNEV

item.title: Second Afghan Governor Defies Kabul Order to Resign, Adding to U.S. Headache
item.media:description: A billboard in northern Afghanistan depicting Atta Mohammad Noor, the governor of Balkh Province who refused to step down when President Ashraf Ghani fired him.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: The refusal by Abdul Karim Khadam, who leads Samangan Province, to step down deepened a political schism between President Ashraf Ghani and regional leaders.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: What a Soldier Killed in Niger Left Behind
item.description: Jenna was relieved when her boyfriend, a U.S. Special Forces soldier, told her he was deploying to Africa, rather than to a war zone like Iraq or Afghanistan. When he was killed in an ambush in Niger, she was left with the fragments of their imagined future.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: President or Luxury Towers: Either Way, Trump Is the Rage in India
item.media:description: Construction workers passing the site where ground will soon be broken for a Trump development in Gurgaon, India. President Trump’s eldest son is expected to arrive in India on Monday to help sell luxury residential units.
item.description: President Trump’s eldest son is headed to India on a sales trip for the family’s real estate business. Indians are star-struck by a family both rich and famous.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and ERIC LIPTON

item.title: A Drifting UKIP Ousts Leader at Center of Racism Row
item.media:description: Henry Bolton in January. The party voted to oust him as leader on Saturday.
item.description: Henry Bolton, a former army officer, was removed as the head of the party after his girlfriend’s racist text messages were published in a tabloid.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Pakistan Serial Killer Sentenced to Death for Murder and Rape of Girl, 7
item.media:description: A vigil last month in Islamabad, Pakistan, for Zainab Amin, a 7-year-old girl who was raped and murdered. Her killer was sentenced to death on Saturday.
item.description: The case caused nationwide outrage and put a spotlight on child sexual abuse in Pakistan. During the trial, the killer, Imran Ali, confessed to seven murders.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Fierce but Frail, Malaysia’s Mahathir, 92, Aims to Topple Protégé
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, now an opposition candidate for the post, in the western town of Sekinchan last month.
item.description: A longtime leader, the former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has allied with opposition figures he once repressed to try to get his old job back in a coming election.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Fire Strikes Hallowed Site in Tibet, the Jokhang Temple in Lhasa
item.description: It was unclear how much damage the blaze did to the ancient Buddhist temple. But to many Tibetans, any harm to the site would be a harsh blow.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Trump’s National Security Chief Calls Russian Interference ‘Incontrovertible’
item.media:description: The national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, in Munich on Saturday.
item.description: Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster accused Moscow of engaging in “disinformation, subversion and espionage.” The comments highlighted a sharp division in the White House on how to talk about Russia’s actions.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: On Olympics: Why the Pyeongchang Games Are Different From All the Others
item.media:description: Children playing in front of a neon sculpture at Gangneung Olympic Park. Bright colors abound at these Games.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: South Korea has imprinted its iridescent style on the Olympics, making it a feast for the senses, with bold food, bright colors and brash graphics.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: The Look: The Peculiar Position of India’s Third Gender
item.media:description: Radhika’s “daughters,” as she affectionately calls them, pose for a portrait near their shared settlement in Mumbai, India. The hijra community is hierarchical, such that more experienced and mature hijras act as guardians and superiors to younger hijras.
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times
item.description: Hijras occupy a special place in Hinduism. But their relationship to modern Mumbai, where transgender people are legally recognized, remains fraught.
item.dc:creator: SARA HYLTON, JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and EVE LYONS

item.title: Three Suicide Bombers Kill at Least 20 in Nigeria
item.description: The attackers, all believed to be women, targeted a fish market in Maiduguri, the Nigerian city that gave rise to the Islamist militants of Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Earthquake Strikes in Oaxaca State, Mexico, Stirring Fear
item.media:description: People embracing in Mexico City, where the effects of a powerful earthquake about 225 miles away were felt.
item.description: No deaths were immediately reported from the 7.2-magnitude quake, but 13 people were killed when a helicopter bringing officials to a town near the epicenter crashed.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Florida, Russia, Turkey: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Citing Hostility, Leader of Anti-Corruption Panel in Honduras Resigns
item.media:description: Juan Jiménez Mayor, who resigned as the leader of an international anti-corruption panel in Honduras, said his group felt abandoned.
item.description: The head of the panel, appointed by the Organization of American States, said his group of prosecutors lacked support from the regional body and the Honduran government.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Canadian Olympic Success, a #MeToo Event and Saskatoon: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: North Korean figure skaters Kim Ju-Sik and Ryom Tae-Ok during a practice session.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: In this week’s Canada Letter a reporter at the Olympics takes questions about the country’s performance so far and we highlight a new landmark on the prairies.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: As Kenya Political Stalemate Drags On, U.S. Becomes a Target
item.media:description: Supporters of Kenya’s opposition leader Raila Odinga burned an American flag near the United States Embassy in Nairobi on Friday.
item.description: The opposition coalition is beginning to fray, but some of its supporters are doubling down — by burning American flags.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin, Russian Oligarch Indicted by U.S., Is Known as ‘Putin’s Cook’
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, left, serving dinner to President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow in 2011, when Mr. Putin was prime minister.
item.description: The secretive oligarch is one of 13 Russians the special counsel charged on Friday for allegedly meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Final Resting Place for Danish Prince Who Yearned to Be King: Not Beside the Queen
item.media:description: Danes at a memorial for Prince Henrik in front of Amalienborg Palace in Copenhagen, Denmark, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mads Claus Rasmussen
item.description: The wishes of Prince Henrik, husband of Queen Margrethe II, who considered his title a mark of gender inequality and died at 83, break royal tradition.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN

item.title: Brazil’s Military Is Put in Charge of Security in Rio de Janeiro
item.media:description: Brazilian soldiers searching a resident during a joint operation in the Cidade de Deus favela in Rio de Janeiro this month.
item.description: President Michel Temer’s security order for Rio is the first such military intervention in a Brazilian state since democracy returned in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO and SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Turkey and U.S. in Talks on Worsening Syria Crisis
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, right, and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson in Ankara on Friday.
item.description: Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan spoke for hours but agreed little on tough questions that divide the NATO allies.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: For 8 Days, Syria Felt More Like World War III
item.description: Over the course of just eight days in February, the conflict in Syria intensified, with the U.S., Russia, Turkey, Israel and Iran all playing a part. Here’s how one of the most chaotic weeks in the seven-year war unfolded.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: With Blackface and Monkey Suit, Chinese Gala on Africa Causes Uproar
item.media:description: A still image from China’s Lunar New Year television show, in which a Chinese actress in blackface and giant fake buttocks depicts an African character.
item.description: A skit in the annual Lunar New Year gala, which is broadcast live to millions, aimed to accentuate African ties. But many found the portrayals offensive.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Milorad Dodik Wants to Carve Up Bosnia. Peacefully, if Possible
item.media:description: Milorad Dodik, center, president of the Serb autonomous region in Bosnia and Herzegovina, celebrating after a referendum on whether to honor the day Radovan Karadzic declared a Serb-only state in Bosnia.
item.media:credit: Samir Yordamovic/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: As the president of the country’s Serbian enclave, Mr. Dodik argues that “Bosnia and Herzegovina is an arranged state, and we want out.”
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: Turkey’s Effort to Repair Relations Trips Over Its Crackdown
item.media:description: A placard, second from right, reading “Stop hunting opposition journalists — Freedom to Deniz Yucel” during a demonstration in Istanbul in October. Mr. Yucel, a German-Turkish journalist, was jailed for a year on accusations of spreading terrorism-related propaganda.
item.description: Sentences handed down to journalists signal an intensifying campaign against independent news in Turkey, even as one reporter was released after a year in custody.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Seeing Bounty Abroad, Will North Koreans Change Their Homeland?
item.description: At the Olympics, curious onlookers scrutinize visitors from the isolated North and wonder what a peek at a broader world could achieve.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Two Swiss Athletes Are First at Olympics Confirmed With Norovirus
item.media:description: Nearly 250 people, including security workers and members of the Olympic organizing committee, have been affected by norovirus at the Pyeongchang Games.
item.media:credit: Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The Swiss Olympic delegation, which did not identify the athletes or their sport, said they were sequestered and no longer had symptoms.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Kosovo Journal: Kosovo Finds Little to Celebrate After 10 Years of Independence
item.media:description: 2018: Children walking by a mural celebrating the Kosovo Liberation Army in Rufc i Ri. Saturday is the 10th anniversary of Kosovo’s declaration of independence, but corruption and a stagnant economy give its people little to celebrate.
item.description: I first came to Kosovo nearly 20 years ago, when NATO intervened against Serbia in the war. A recent visit showed optimism yielding to fear and resignation.
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by ANDREW TESTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
